newsitem.title: USA: OPTIONS - U.S. T-bond vols stay soft, June expires.
newsitem.headline: OPTIONS - U.S. T-bond vols stay soft, June expires.

text.p: Implied volatilities for U.S. Treasury bond options remained soft as the underlying bond prices stayed within recent tight ranges and the weekend time-decay weighed on premiums, dealers said.
June T-bond futures options on Chicago Board of Trade (CBOT) expired at noon without causing any significant turbulence, they added.

"It (expiration) was really a non-event, especially with the market trading at the 110-handle," a broker at CBOT said. "If you recall, May (options) went out at 108-even a month ago. Well, here we are again."
Traders have pointed at the high level of open interest in the 110 strike price as one of the reasons for June T-bond futures' range-trade around 110 in recent sessions.

The at-the-money strike price tends to have a magnetic effect when expiration approaches as delta-hedgers who have the gamma-rich, short-dated contracts tend to be forced to quickly sell futures when the market goes up and buy futures when the market goes down.
For instance, a call option holder's delta increases as futures rise, generating the need to sell futures to keep delta near zero.
Likewise, put options' negative delta decreases as futures go up, also calling for futures selling.
Shorter maturities have higher gamma, the rate of change in delta per move in the underlying asset price.

Many delta-neutral market-makers were thought to have been on the long side in gamma lately because of end-users' general reluctance to buy options, which has been evidenced in the steady erosion of implied volatilities, traders said.
Still, caution ahead of next Tuesday's Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting underpinned volatilities, even though it was also dampening bond price movement.
Implied volatility for CBOT July and September T-bond futures options stood at around 8.4 percent and 8.6 percent, off about 0.1 each.
"No one is sure if the Fed's going to do it or not," said a second CBOT trader, referring to possible credit tightening at the FOMC meeting. "It's a close call."
T-bond futures ended off 11/32 at 109-31/32, just 1/32 below the 110-strike price.
In the Eurodollar market at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange (CME), option trading was relatively calm, with several apparent hedge deals in the front-June options.
A CME floor analyst at a European bank noted that a lot of slightly out-of-the-money June 94.00 traded today.
"It appears to be a hedge against cash books," he said.

He said there was little dealing interest like that Thursday, when a lot of short-Junes -- options expiring next month but priced off 1998 futures -- traded. Because front-month futures gravitate toward cash deposit rates near expiration, Eurodollar option trading usually focuses on a few quarters out or the mid-curves like short-June.
Implied volatilities for September and December Eurodollar options softened a touch to 9.2 and 11.5 percent respectively.
-- Shin Kishima/Chicago Derivatives Desk ((312-408-8750))
